sourceDesc.p: Created from original research by members of CWRC/CSÉC unless otherwise noted.

div.head: C 9/317/3 [IMG_9526; IMG 9528]
div.p:
Jurat 16 die December 1704
Coram me
Christopher Rich
Thomas Pitt
Henry Mordant & Francis Stanhope Esquire
Thomas Pitt
Dec 14 1704
Thomas Skipwith Jurat 18th Die
Decemberis 1704 Coram me S: Keck
The Joint & Severall Answers of Sir Thomas Skipwith Baronet Christopher Rich Esquire Henry Mordant & Francis Stanhope Esquire Fower of the Defendants to the amended Bill
of Complaynt of Charles Killigrew Esquire Dame Penelope Morley widdow, Thomas Clayton gentleman, Thomas Nappier Esquire Thomas Kinaston Merger and John Sherman gentleman Complaynants.
The Defendants Severally & respectively saveing & reserving to themselves & to every of them now & at all times hereafter all & all manner of Advantage & Benefitt of exception that may be had or taken to the manifold Errors untruths uncerteinties Insufficiencies and
Imperfections in the Complaynants said Bill of Complaynt conteyned For answer thereunto or unto soe much thereof as is materiall for these Defendants or either of them (as they are advised) to make answere unto, these Defendants (each answering for himselfe and not
answer for the other of them) Severally & say That they have heard & beleive it may be true That the Complaynant Charles Killigrew Together with Margarett Lacy, Thomas Morley Esquire, afterwards Sir Thomas Morley knight Thomas Shepey Joseph Nickens Henry Titchborne,
Charles Hart Nicholas Burt William Cartwright William Clayton Richard Burt John Tombes & Nicholas Strawbridge in the Bill named were in or about the Yeare of our Lord One thousand six hundred Eighty & three possessed of or interested in a Certein Messuage or Tenement commonly called or
known by the name of the Theatre Royall Situate & being in the parishes of St. Martins in the Feilds & St. Paul Covent Garden or one of them for all the residue of a term of Forty & One Yeares which was then to come & unexpired granted unto some of them & to others under when thereof
of them claymed or to some others in trust for them by the right noble William then Earle & afterwards Duke of Bedford By Indenture of Lease beareing date on or about the 20th day of December One thousand six hundred sixty & one att & under the Yearely Rent of Fifty pounds payable
halfe yearely as in the said Bill is sett forth Which said Messuage or Tenement was as these Defendants have heard & beleive built & Erected at the proper costs & charges of Thomas Killigrew Esquire late Father of the Complaynant Charles Killigrew & of severall other persons whom he took in as partners
by vertue of the Lords Patents herein after mencioned to be granted to the said Thomas Killigrew his heires & assignes to Erect one or more Theatre or Theatres And these Defendants have heard & beleive That the said Complaynant Charles Killigrew & the rest of the said persons in the said Complaynts
Bill for that purpose named being soe possessed or interested Did by Indentures beareing date on or about the Seaventh day of June in the thirty & fifth yeare of the Raigne of his late Majestie King Charles the Second & in the said yeare of our Lord 1683 made or mencioned to be made between
the Said Complaynant Killigrew & the rest of the Said persons in the Said Bill for that purpose named of the one part & Charles Davenant of London Doctor of Lawes Thomas Betterton & William Smith of London gentleman of the other part Demise unto the Said Charles Davenant All those their Severall
Shares parts Interests & proporcions of & in all that the Said Messuage or Tenement called the Theatre Royall with the appertenances (Except as therein is excepted) To have & to hold from the Ninth day of November then last past before the date of the Said Indenture for the terme of Nineteen
yeares thence next ensueing Yeilding & paying therefore upon every day or time that any Play Comedy Tragedy Opera or publick Representacion of the Stage should be publickly acted or performed either in the Said Theatre thereby devised or in Theatre called the Duke of Yorkes Theatre in Dorsett Garden
near Fleet Street London or in any other Theatre or Theatres place or places within the City of London & Westminster or either of them or the Suburbs thereof or within the compass or extent of the Bill of Mortality by the Company usually acting in or belonging to the said Dukes Theatre or the person who
should succeed them to Act therein or any other persons in Company under any Patent or Patents granted or assigned unto the said Thomas Killigrew or Sir Wiliam Davenant or their or either of their assignee or assignes The Severall & respective dayly summes or Rents in the Said Lease mencioned
(that is to say) To the Complaynant Charles Killigrew his Executors administrators & assignes the Summe of Fifteen shillings & to the said Thomas Morley Thomas Shepey Joseph Nickens Henry Titchborne Charles Hart Nicholas Burt William Cartwright William Clayton Richard Burt John Tombes
Margarett Lacy & Richard Strawbridge & their respective Executors Administrators & assignes two pounds & five shillings in such proporcions as in the Said Complaynants Bill is mencioned amounting in all (with the Said fifteen Shilling) use three pounds per diem on such Acting Dayes aforesaid And these
Defendants beleive that the said Doctor Davenant Covenanted to pay the Said rents referred & payable to the Said Complaynant Killigrew & the rest of the Said Lessors but for more certeinly in all & every the matters aforesaid these Defendants referr themselves unto the Said Lease or any Counter
part thereof when the same shall be produced to this honourable Court And these Defendants further say That they have heard & doe beleive That the Said Lease was soe made unto the said Doctor Davenant in pursueance of & was meant & intended to be used & enjoyed Subject to the Covenants and
Agreements & for the intents & purposes conteyned in one Indenture beareing date the fowerth day of May in the yeare of our Lord One thousand six hundred Eighty & two made or mencioned to be made between the said Complaynant Killigrew by the name of Charles Killigrew Esquire Master of his
Majesties Revells on the one part & the said Doctor Davenant Thomas Betterton & William Smith on the other part In which last Indenture it being amongst other things recited to the effect herein after sett forth (vizt.) That his late Majestie King Charles the second had by his Lords Patents under the
great Seale of England beareing date the Five & twentieth day of Aprill in the fourteenth yeare of his Reign given & granted unto Thomas Killigrew Esquire one of the Gromes of his Bedchamber his heires & assignes full power to Erect & build One Theatre or Playhouse with the appurtenances
within London & Westminster or the Suburbs thereof & to entertaine Players & others to Act & represent Tragedies Commedies Playes & other Entertainments of the Stage & that in pursueance of the Said Lords Patents One Theatre had been erected in or near Covent Garden called The Kings Playhouse
wherein Playes had been frequently acted and alsoe renting that the now Complaynant Killigrew then claymed the right to dispose of the Said Lords Patents and priviledges in and by the same granted and alsoe the right to dispose of the same Theatre soe erected; and
alsoe reciting that his said late Majestye King Charles the second had by his Letters patents under the greate seale of England beareing date on or about the Fifteenth day of January in the same Fourteenth yeare of his Raigne given and
granted unto Sir William Davenant the heires Executors Administrators and Assignes full power and authority to erect and build one other Theatre or playhouse with the appurtenances within the said Cityes of London or Westminster or the Suburbs thereof and to
entertaine players & others to act & represent Tragedyes Commedyes playes & other Entertainments of the stage and that in pursueance of the said last mencioned Letters patents one other Theatre called the Dukes playhouse had been erected in
or neare Dorsett Garden London wherein playes had been frequently acted and alsoe reciting that the said Charles Davenant then claymed the right to dispose of the last mencioned Letters patents and priviledges by the same granted
And reciting that the said Betterton and Smith claymed some power & right to the same by from or under the said Sir William Davenant or the said Dr. Davenant and there upon it was (inter alia) agreed upon by and between all the
partyes to the last mencioned Indenture that all the powers authorityes priviledges & benefitts granted by the said first recited Letters patents should be joyned and united to the powers authorityes Benefitts and priviledges granted
by the said second Letters patents and that from thenceforth the same should be as one and soe forever after continue and be Subject onely to the agreements in the same Indenture contayned And further that all playes then after to be acted by vertue
of the said Letters patents or either of them should be acted & performed by the Company then employed or then after to be Employed at the said Theatre in Dorsett Garden And the said now Complaynant Charles Killigrew did Covenant to dissolve
the Company of players belonging to the said Kings playhouse within Six dayes then next and within the same time to deliver up unto the said Doctor Davenant his heires or assignes all the playes perticularly mencioned in a Schedule
thereto annexed and further that the full and peaceable possession of the said Theatre Royall with all the matters and things thereto belonging that had been used therefore acting of playes (The Scenes & Scene Roomes onely Excepted) free
from all charges and Incumbrances whatsoever should be delivered up to the said Dr. Davenant his heires and assignes to and for the sole use of the said thereby united Letters patents and for the true Intents & purposes in the same Indenture
of Union mencioned and that the same should bee then after from time to time held enjoyed and employed for the acting of playes Operas and Entertainments of the Stage there when it should be thought expedient and by Such person and
[IMG_9530; IMG_9531]
persons and Company as should be from time to time directed and appoynted by the said Charles Killigrew and the said Dr. Davenant their respective heires and assignes The said Dr Davenant his heires & assignes paying for the same from the time of the delivering the posession
theref unto the said Complaynant Killigrew his heires & assignes the Rent or Summe of Three pound per diem for every day any play should be publickly acted in pursueance of the said last Indenture att either of the said Theatres or att any other place within London & Westminster or the
suburbs thereof And these Defendants say that they take it that it dothe manifestly appeare in and by the said last recited Indentures That the said Lease soe made of the said Theatre Royall to Dr Davenant as aforesaid was made in
pursueance thereof and for the Intents and purposes therein exprest And these Defendants beleive that for such Intents and purposes the said Dr. Davenant or his assignes entered the said Theatre with the appurtenances & held and enjoyed the
same in Nature of a trust for the acting of Playes and other Entertainements of the Stage for the Benefitt of the Complaynant Killigrew and of the said Dr Davenant and such other person & persons as then were or should be interested in
the cleere profitts to be made of or by acting of playes pursueant to the said Indenture of Union the same cleere profitts being thereby agreed or mencioned to be from time to time divided into twenty equall parts or shares whereof the Complaynant
Killigrew to have three parts And these Defendants Sir Thomas Skipwith and Christopher Rich further say that the cleere profitts arising by acting being by the said Indenture of union to be divided into twenty equall parts or shares whereof the said
Complaynant Killigrew or his assignes to have there party as aforesaid and the remaineing Seaventeen parts or shares thereof being againe divided or putt in to twenty equall parts or shares And Sixteen of last mencioned twenty parts or shares
being claymed by severall persons commonly called Adventurers or Sharers Adventurers by vertue of grants from the said Sir William Davenant or the said Dr. Davenant or Dame Mary Davenant the widdow & Relaction of the said Sir William Davenant And the said Dr Davenant (being Interested in the Fower remaining
shares of the said last mencioned twenty shares or of some shares of the cleere profitts of and by acting and being alsoe Interested in the said Lease made to him of the said Theatre Royall and Interested in the said Letters Patents granted to
the said Sir William Davenant and alsoe Interested by vertue of the said Indenture of Union as aforesaid) he the said Dr Davenant as these Defendants Skipwith and Rich have been informed & doe beleive did by severall Indentures beareing date
on or about the thirtyeth day of August Anno Domini 1687 Convey and assigne to Alexander Davenant thereof the parish St. Bridgetts alsoe St. Brides London All his the said Doctor Davenants shares of and in the profitt arising by acting
and alsoe the said Indenture of Lease made to him of the said Theatre Royall and all his right title & Interest in and to the said Letters patents granted to Sir William Davenant the heires & assignes and the powers leines and authorityes thereby granted and
the full Benefitt and advantage thereof and all the playes mencioned in the schedule annexed to the said Indenture of union And all his Interest in the Apparrell Scenes Cloathes or Furniture commonly used or worne or belonging to the acting
of playes And all and Singular Covenants Grants and Agreements in the said last mencioned Indenture conteyned on the part of the said Complaynant Charles Killigrew his heires Executors Administrators & assignes to be done and performed and the full
force and effect thereof and all his the said Dr Davenants right Title & Interest in and to the premisses respectively (Except as in the said Severall Indentures of the thirtyeth of August as Excepted) To have & to hold the premisses
unto the said Alexander Davenant his heires Executors Administrators and Assignes To his and their onely use & behoofe as in and by the same Indentures & to which these Defendants referr themselves when the same shall be produced may more att
large appears And these Defendants Skipwith & Rich Say & hope to prove to this honourable Court That afterwards the said Alexander Davenant in or by one Indenture beareing date on or about the fower and twentieth day of March Anno
Domini 1690 Conveyed & assigned All & singular the premisses soe purchased by him of the said Charles Davenant as aforesaid unto him this Defendant Rich his heires executors administrators & assignes To the onely uses & behoofe of this Defendant Rich his heires
Executors administrators & assignes Nevertheless as to severall proportions thereof the named of this Defendant Rich was made use of In trust for the Defendant Sir Thomas Skipwith As in & by the said Last Indenture & to which and the Declaracions of trust concerning the same
premisses these Defendants referr themselves it doth & may appeare And these Defendants Skipwith & Rich say that it was Agreed that the said Alexander Davenant might & should have Libertie to Redeem the said purchased premisses upon payment of two thousand three hundred & fifty pounds to these Defendants in the
proporcions agreed on at the end of Seaven yeares But these Defendants say Each answering for himselfe That the said Alexander Davenant hath not paid to these Defendants or either of them the said 2350£ or any part thereof nor hath he released to these Defendants or either of them the Equity of Redempcion of the same
premisses And these Defendants Skipworth & Rich further say That they being alsoe interrested respectively in some other Shares of the cleer profitts ariseing by Acting under the said Patents or one of them And being alsoe interested respectively of some parts or proporcions of the Rent of
Seaven pounds per diem heretofore usually paid on Acting dayes for the said Theatre in Dorsett Garden as Building Proprietors thereof or Purchasors under them or some of them And this Defendant Rich being then alsoe interested in some part or Share of the said Theatre Royall & of Some
Share or proportion of the three pounds per diem payable for the same by vertue of or under the said Lease granted by the said William then Earle & afterwards Duke of Bedford since deceased Hee this Defendant Rich in or about the begining of the Month of November which was in the yeare
of our Lord One thousand six hundred Ninety & three Entred upon & took possession of the said Theatre Royall with the appurtenances and alsoe took upon himselfe the Management of the premisses in Conjunction with the said Sir Thomas Skipwith & Charles Killigrew and he this Defendant
Rich hath ever since continued to hold enjoy & keep the possession of the said Theatre Royall which (as he is advised) he had & hath right to doe & hath used & employed the same for the Acting of Playes Opera's & Entertainments of the Stage for the benefitt of himselfe & others in nature of a Trust
for the sole use of the said united Lords Patents & for the true intents & purposes in the said Indenture of Union conteyned for the use of all persons lawfully interested & concerned therein And these Defendants Skipwith & Rich further say That they beleive Itt was further Agreed in or by the said Indenture of Union
That if at any time after the delivery of the possession of the said Theatre Royall to the said Doctor Davenant That he the said Doctor Davenant his heires or assignes or any other persons then after to Act there according to the intent of the Same Indenture should be interrupted in the quiet Enjoying of
the Same Theatre for the purpose aforesaid then the said three pounds per diem to cease untill such interrupcion removed, And these Defendants Skipwith & Rich beleive that it was further agreed by the Said Indenture of Union That from thenceforth forever All the cleer profitts of & by acting in the said Theatre
or either of them or elsewhere (after all charges certeine & indenture paid & deducted) that should then after be had or made by the said Union Patents or pursueant to the Same Indenture should be divided into twenty Equall parts or Shares and three whole parts or Shares thereof should be from
[f. 2 IMG_9518 and IMG_9520]
time to time paid unto the said complainant Killigrew his heirs executors administrators & assignes (vizt) One Share & one halfe of a share to be paid to him or them upon the Account of Dissolving of the said Company & transferring of the said Plays and for discharging of severall debts amounting to about Two Hundred pounds
contracted by the said Royall Company And the other Share & one halfe of a Share to be paid to him & them in recompence of his & their right to the said first recited Lords Patents as in & by the said Indenture of Union & to which these Defendents for more certeinty in the particular last use mencioned doe alsoe reserr themselves it doth & may fully appeare
And all these defendants say That they beleive it to be true That the said William Duke of Bedford by Indenture bearing date on or about the nine & twentyeth day of June Anno Domini 1695 Did Lease and to Farme Lett unto the now Complaynant John Sherman and
to John Warter in the Bill named their Executors administrators and assignes at & by the direccion and appoyntment of the Complaynant Killigrew Dame Penelope Morley and other persons in the Bill for that purpose mencioned the said Theatre Royall with the appurtenances
(Except as therein is Excepted) To hold from the Feast of the Birth of our Lord God which was in the year of our Lord one thousand six hundred Seaventy and two for the Terme of Fourteen Years thence next ensueing at & under the Yearly Rent of Fifty pounds payable
halfe yearly And all these Defendants further say That they beleive that the said John Sherman & John Warter did by severall writeings under their hands & seales declare that their names were made of the said last mencioned Lease in Trust for the Complaynant Charles Killigrew & the Rest
the partyes in the said Lease for that purpose named for such shares and parts as they then had or Claymed in the said Theatre by & under the said originall Lease & by severall Deeds & writeings under their hands & seales Duely executed Did assigne & sett over unto the said
Complaynant Killigrew Nine six & thirty parts or shares of the said Theatre & lease last Granted & to the rest of the persons in the Bill for that purpose named such shares and proporcioned as is & are therein sett forth And these Defendants beleive that in such writings or
Declaracions of Trust or assignements last herein mencioned they the said Complaynants Charles Killigrew Dame Penelope Morley and Thomas Nappier and alsoe Margarett Lacy Thomas Shepey Mary Scroop George Bradbury Thomas Stringer Richard Symes
Henry Mordant Edward Kinaston Edward Watty James Stone Richard Bentley and Henry Hale Respectively their respective Executors Administrators and assignes was and were att his and their owne costs and Charges to beare and pay his her & their proporcion and
proporcions according to their respective Equitable Interests therein and thereby declared of the said Rent of Fifty pounds per annum reserved as aforesaid on the said Lease granted by the said William Duke of Bedford for the said Terms of Fourteen yeares and
alsoe all and every such Summe and Summes of money as should be from time to time expended bestowed or laid out in and about the Repairacions of the premisses and for Taxes and Assessments and of all Losses Costs Charges Damages and Expences that should
or might happen grow or arise to the said John Sherman and John Warter their Executors or Administrators by reason of any the Reservacions or Covenants conteyned in the said last mencioned Lease or other wise But for more Certainty in all the
perticulars aforesaid these Defendants referre themselves to the said Lease and Deeds of Trust and Assignments last mencioned when the same shall be produced to this honourable Court, And all these Defendants say (each answering for himselfe) that they doe not know whether
the Complaynants any or either of them is or are now possessed and Interested of and in such parts shares or proporcions of the said Theatre Royall or of the said Rent of three pounds per diem claymed to be payable for the same as in the Bill is alleadged Nor doe
these Defendants know (each answering for himselfe) what part shares or proporcions of the premisses the severall Complaynants any or either of them is or are now possessed of or interested in, But this Defendant Henry Mordant sayth that he doth clayme and is
justly intitled and interested as he is advised and beleives of in and to One thirty Sixth part (the whole in thirty Six Equall parts to be divided) of the said Theatre Royall with the appurtenances and of all Rents and profitts due and payable for the same for the Residue of
the said Terme of Fourteen yeares yett to come and unexpired And this Defendant Francis Stanhope Saith that he doth clayme and is justly intitled and Interested as he is advised and beleives of in and to One other thirty Sixth part (the whole in thirty six equall parts to be divided
as aforesaid of and in the said Theatre Royall with the appurtenances and of all Rents and profitts due and payable for the same for the residue of the said Terme of Fourteen yeares yett to come and unexpired And these said Defendant Rich referrs and says that the said Complaynants Thomas
Clayton and Thomas Napier since the amendment of the said Complaynants Bill did execute the Severall acquittances following viz. Hee the said Thomas Clayton by writing under his hand and seale and beareing date the thirtyeth day of November Anno Domini
1704 did therein and thereby acknowledge to have received of this Defendant Christopher Rich the Summe of Forty pounds thirteen shillings and Fower pence which he did acknowledge to be full payment of all Rent & Rents and Arrears of Rent & Rents due and ending on
the day of the date thereof unto him the said Complaynant and unto Charles Longland Elizabeth his wife and Margarett Clayton Spinster for their Fouer parts the whole in thirty and six equall parts being divided of the Rent of three pounds per diem payable for the said theatre
Royall with the appurtences and which he xxxxt and allowed as Executor of the last will and Testament of William Clayton his late Father deceased and alsoe as Executor of the last will and Testament of Elizabeth Clayton his late Mother deceased and by vertue of a letter
of Attorney from the said Charles Longland and Margarett Clayton bearing date the twentyeth day of March Anno Domini 1698 and alsoe by vertue of another Letter of Attorney from the said Charles Longland and Elizabeth his wife bearing date the third
day of Aprill anno Domini 1700 in full of all Rents due to them Respectively for their shares of and in the said Theatre with the appurtences into and ending the day of the date thereof And the said Complaynant Thomas Nappier by a Note in Writing under
his hand beareing date the one and thirtyeth day of October 1704 acknowledged to have received of the Defendant Christopher Rich the Summe of Fower pounds Sixteen shillings and Eight pence for Eleaven dayes Rent in June then last, Six dayes in July, Nine dayes in August
Eleaven dayes in September and one and twenty dayes in that present October in full for his Rent of One Shilling and Eight pence per diem for his one six and thirtyeth part of the Theatre Royall unto and ending that one and thirtyeth day of October 1704 as
in and by the said severall Receipts Relacion being thereunto respectively had and to which this Defendant Rich for his more certainty therein referreth himselfe and ready to be produced it doth and may more fully appeare And this Defendant Sir Thomas Skipwith by
himselfe Saith that he hath not or claymeth to have any right title share or Interest in the said Theatre Royall or any share part or proporcion thereof or of the said Rent of three pounds per diem in the Bill mencioned or any share or part thereof But this Defendant Sir Thomas
Skipwith claymes severall shares of the cleer neate profitts by acting in the said Theatre Royall ariseing after payment of all charges constant and Incident commonly called Adventures Shares And both these Defendants Skipwith and Rich severally Say & Deny
that the Complaynants or any or either of them otherwise then by their originall Bill of Complaint account of these Defendants in this honourable Court ever acquainted these Defendants or either of them
with any Such or the like Agreement as by them or any or either of them in their Bill is mencioned to be had or made with the said other Defendants Thomas Betterton and John Watson for granting &
Leasing of the said Theatre house and premisses to them or either of them for the Rent of Five pounds per diem or any other Rent or offered or propose the same to these Defendants or either of them under the Rent of Six pounds per diem
But this Defendant Rich Sayth that after the exhibiting of the said originall Bill of Complaynt to within or about the Month of October one thousand seaven hundred & two the said John Sherman now named to be one of the Complaynants For much
Importunity shewed unto this Defendant Rich Certaine articles or pretended articles of Agreement to such or the like offer as in the Bill is Sett forth and pretended to be liquid and executed by all or some of the Complaynants as the said Mr Sherman pretended And both these
Defendants Skipwith & Rich Say That they have not nor either of them hath to the knowledge of each other gone about or endeavored to perswade them the said other Defendants Betterton & Watson or either of them from executing any Counterpart of the pretended Lease in the Bill mencioned & pretended to be made or agreed to be made & granted to them or either of them But
on the contrary these Defendants verily beleived & are assured That they the said other Defendants Betterton & Watson or at least the said Defendant Betterton are or is in the Combinacion & Confederacy with the now Complaynant Some or one of them to Evict & turn this Defendant Rich out of the possession of the said Theatre house & premisses called the Theatre Royall & to deprive the said Defendants
of their severall parts rights & Shares therein & the fruit & benefitt of the said Lords Patents made & granted for acting of Playes in the Bill mencioned & to Lubrert & Vestrey the said Union Settlement thereof, the said Betterton haveing acted in apparent breach & Violacion thereof as these Defendants beleive & hope & doubt not but to & were as occasion shall &
may require And the Defendant Rich Sayth That he hath been putt to great expence & trouble in defence of a Writ of Particion which in or about Trinity Terme Anno Domini 1702 was brought in the name of the now Complaynant Thomas Nappier as Demandant & presented in her Majesties Court of Common Pleas at Wishener against this Defendant Christopher Rich
& the severall persons following were alsoe named Defendants therein To wit Charles Killigrew Esquire Margarett Lacy widdow Thomas Clayton gentleman John Sherman gentleman Thomas Musters gentleman Barbara Bradbury Spinster Francis Stanhope Esquire Henry Mordant Esquire Thomas Kinaston Order Fainy gentleman James Stone gentleman Dame Penelope Morley widdow Grace
Davis widdow Henry Hales gentleman & Grace Shepey Spinster The Said Writ being to have a Particion made of the said Made Snagger Terme under called the Theatre Royall with the appoyntments To which Writ the Defendant putt in his Plea & the same Cause is Still depending As by the said Writt of Particion & plea & the Proceedings therein Remayning as of Reward in the said Court of
Common Pleas & to which the Defendant for the more certeynty thereof referreth himselfe it doth & may appease And the Defendant Rich further sayth That he hath been also putt to great expence & charge in defence of An Action in Ejectment brought in her Majesties Court of Queene Bench at Westminster & in the name of John Johnson as Like
of the now Complaynant Charles Killigrew Dame Penelope Morley Thomas Clayton Thomas Nappier Thomas Kinaston & John Sherman & alsoe as Listed of the said Margarett Lacy Henry Mordant Francis Stanhope Grace Shepey Anne Davies & Henry Hales in or about Michaelmas Term 1701 for Recovery of the possession of the said Messuage
or Tenement called the Theatre Royall with the appurtenances or of some parts thereof To which Action of Ejectment this Defendant appeared & putt in his plea & issue was Joyned & Severall Proceedings therein had But the Same Cause hath not as yet been brought on to be tryed but is Still depending As by the said Action & Proceedings last mencioned
& to which this Defendant Rich for more certeynly therein referreth himselfe it doth & may appeare And this Defendant Rich Sayeth That he being intitled as aforesaid & being interested in Severall Shares parts & proporcions of the said Theatre Royall with the appurtenances & haveing a Right to how the Same as he was & is advised by wrtnd of the said Indenture
of Union (as assignes of Alexander Davenant who was assignee of the said Doctor Davenant as aforesaid) for the uses intents & purposes in the said Indenture of Union mencioned He the Defendant hath laid out & expended great Summes of money in & about the Alteracions Reparacions & Decorations of the said Theatre Royall
& appurtenances Whereby the Same is much Meliorated & improved as this Defendant hopes to prove and hath laid out moneys to pay the Taxes charges on or in respect of the premisses by Acts of Parliament & otherwise And therefore and for the reasons herein before contayned And alsoe for that the said perleadeds
Articles & Lease to & with the said Betterton & Watson is & fraudulently & deceitfully penned as the Defendant is advised & for severall other reasons this Defendant doth refuse & is not willing to Joyn in the Execucion of the Same pretended Articles & Lease And these Defendants Henry Mordant & Francis Stanhope
say That for the severall reasons in this Answere herein before mencioned thse Defendants are not willing to Joyn in the Execution of the pretended Articles or Lease last mencioned But are willing & desireous That he the Said Defendant Rich by vertue of the Assignments from the Said Dr Davenant & Alexander Davenant as
aforesaid shall & may hold & enjoy the Said Theatre Royall with the appertenances at & under the said Rate of Three pounds per diem on public & acting dayes according to the true intent & meaning of the said Indenture of Union of the Fowerth of May Anno Domini 1682 and for the uses intents & purposes therein
expressed And all these Defendants doe severally deny all & all manner of unlawfull Combinacion & confederacy whatsoever in & by the said Complaynants said Bill laid to these Defendants or either of their change to or with all or any or either of the other Defendants in the Bill named or any other person or
persons whatsoever for all or any the ends & purposes therein mencioned or any other Unlawfull end or purpose whatsoever Without that that there is any other matter or thing clause sentence or Allegation in the Complaynants said Bill of Complaynt conteyned materiall or effectuall in the Law further
Defendant or Either of them as they are advised to make answers unto and not herein & hereby well & Sufficiently answered unto Confessed or avoyded traversed or denyed is true to the knowledge of these Defendants All which matters & things these Defendants and & Shall be ready to Averr In stilye mainteyne and prove as this honourable
Court Shall direct and humbly pray to be hence dismissed with their reasonable cost & charges in this behalfe most wrongfully Susteyned.
William Nutley
